topic.title: Adding Tables to a DITA Topic

body.p: You can add a table to a DITA topic. By default, DITA supports two types of tables, the DITA simple table model, and the OASIS Exchange Table Model (a subset of the CALS table model). If you are using a specialized DITA vocabulary, it may contain specialized versions of these table models.

Because DITA is a structured format, you can only insert a table in places in the structure of a topic where tables are allowed. The DITA toolbar provides support for entering and editing tables. It also indicates where you are allowed to insert a table or its components by graying out the appropriate buttons.

fig.title: The DITA Toolbar
fig.p: The DITA toolbar showing the insert table button available and the table editing buttons grayed out:

ol.li: To insert a DITA simple table, click the table button on the DITA toolbar. The Insert Table dialog appears.
Select the appropriate options for rows and columns, creating a header, column widths, and framing of cells.
Click Insert. The table is inserted.

body.section: Inserting an OASIS Exchange Table Model (CALS) TableTo insert an OASIS Exchange Table, follow the same procedure as above, but choose the CALS model. Additional options for specifying row and column separators and alignment will be enabled.

section.p: When you insert a CALS table, you see a link for setting the colspecs (column specifications) of your table. Click the link to open the colspec controls. Although they appear as part of the Author view, the colspec link and the colspec controls will not appear in your output. They are just there to make it easier to adjust how the columns of your table are formatted.

section.title: Editing an Existing Table
section.p: You can edit the structure of an existing table using the table buttons on the DITA toolbar to add or remove cells, rows, or columns, and to set basic table properties. However, both the DITA simple table and the OASIS Exchange Table (CALS) have many additional attributes, on both the table elements and the row and cell elements, that can be used to fine-tune the formatting of your tables. The easiest way to adjust these attributes is to open the Attributes view ( Window Show View Attributes ). See the DITA documentation for a full explanation of these attributes.
Also, remember that underneath the visual representation, both table models are really just XML, and, if necessary, you can edit the XML directly by switching to Text mode.
